texts.shortText: Elongate eel-like species with a smooth, flexible body lacking scales or paired fins, but tail surrounded by an extensive, rounded fin. Head lacks true (lensed) eyes, but has primitive eyespots and bears six short, tapering barbels around the oval mouth, four pointing forwards and two pointing backwards. Mouth has two extensible rows of horny, comb-like teeth borne on cartilaginous plates that can be everted and retracted to grasp food. Two rows of slime pores and six pairs of gill openings on underside of body. Colour uniform dark grey.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Walvis Bay in Namibia to Durban.

Hagfish are a very primitive group of vertebrates and have a cartilaginous skull and only rudimentary vertebrae. The group has remained virtually unchanged for over 300 million years.

This species is found from the intertidal to depths of up to 400 m and can occur both in crevices on rocky reefs or buried in sediments. It is a scavenger that rapidly gathers around dead or disabled fish, or other organisms, which are torn apart with the teeth, additional traction being created by knotting the body and pulling the head back against the knot. Secretes copious amounts of mucus when handled. Often caught in lobster traps and regarded as a pest by fishers.
Scavenger, feeding on dead or disabled fish, crustaceans, bait or other animal material.

Little is known about reproduction in this species, but other hagfish lay 1–30 large yolky eggs that are sticky and deposited in crevices in the rocks, or beneath the sand. Eggs can take up to 11 months to develop. There is no larval stage.
Unmistakable and the only shallow water hagfish species found in the region.
